repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Maintenance and
            Development Project (RMDP) for Nepal were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: field surveys
            should always be used to complement computerized modeling of
            engineering designs of roads in a mountainous terrain.
            Engineering designs of new roads in RMDP relied exclusively
            on computerized modeling and were not accompanied by field
            surveys. As a result, they had many flaws and were
            inappropriate for local conditions. The revision of designs
            and tender documents of respective civil works triggered
            substantial cost and time overruns in individual contracts.
            Autonomy of a Roads Board is important to ensure stable and
            adequate funding of road maintenance. Experience in the
            South Asia region suggests that creation of a Roads Board is
            not in itself sufficient for efficient and effective
            mobilization and management of maintenance funds. The
            structure of the Board must be such that it can work
            effectively taking into account the prevailing political
            context. Involvement of technical staff in reporting is
            essential for effective financial management. RMDP
            experience suggests that a close collaboration between
            technical and financial management staff creates linkages
            between physical progress and financial progress and thus is
            important to ensure satisfactory financial management.

repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance and Development
            Project supports the Country Assistance Strategy objective
            to reduce poverty in rural areas, by improving rural access,
            and, prompting higher agricultural output, as well as
            non-farm income, in remote hill areas of the country. The
            project components will: 1) support policy reform, through
            the establishment of a Roads Board, the amendment of
            regulatory frameworks, and the development of a Road Fund;
            2) construct dry-weather feeder roads, and, upgrade roads to
            gravel standard, including resettlement assistance,
            environmental monitoring, and, technical assistance
            provision for project design, coordination, and construction
            supervision. The component will further assist on land
            acquisition issues; 3) include the rehabilitation of
            strategic highway, and feeder road network; 4) provide
            measures for periodic maintenance of strategic roads; 5)
            strengthen institutional development of, and provide
            training to, the Department of Roads, and the Ministry of
            Works and Transport. In addition, consulting will be
            included for auditing, pre-investment, and socioeconomic
            studies, and, office modernization, and equipment will be
            improved, and supplied, respectively; and, 6) include a
            Project Preparation Facility to support project preparation
            and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Although the project will improve
            accessibility to essential services, hence provide improved
            economic opportunities, the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP)
            proposes efforts to minimize adverse social impacts,
            continue the ongoing community consultation, develop an
            institutional framework for appropriate management, and,
            spells out that construction work, will only begin after
            land acquisition procedures are successfully initiated. The
            RAP presents mitigation measures to reduce land acquisition
            impacts on affected populations. The shortest possible
            length in road design was selected, to minimize land take,
            and in turn, avoid archaeological/cultural sites, as well as
            conservation or cultivation areas, allowing adjustments for
            the right of way. Through the Entitlement Framework,
            compensation and rehabilitation benefits to affected
            populations will be ensured. Compensation will cover the
            costs due to loss of land, and privately-owned assets, as
            well as adverse individual or collective impacts on
            subsistence, livelihood, or income-earning capacity.
            Payments will be in the form of cash lump sums, or two
            installments, be it for alternative accommodation or final
            replacement. Capacity-building initiatives will be provided,
            including training, and Local Consultative Forums will
            address social issues, inform on grievance resolution
            mechanisms, and monitor for adequate resettlement practices.

Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development
            Project : resettlement action plan

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development
            Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment discusses
            the negative environmental impacts that result from
            constructing five roads, and upgrading other roads, for the
            Road Maintenance and Development Project for Nepal.
            Mitigation measures include limiting the area of disturbance
            and land take, sequencing construction activities to save
            the double handling of materials, installing all major
            retaining and drainage works in the initial year of
            construction (prior to the monsoon), and progressively
            revegetating the completed batters. The pegging of the road
            formation areas and ancillary sites enables works to be
            confined, which reduces the area of disturbance and the loss
            of productive resources. Vegetation clearance will be
            controlled to limit the loss of production resources, damage
            to surrounding features, and ground disturbance and the
            associated erosion hazard. Retaining walls will enable
            backfilling of the wall and reduce the likelihood of fill
            sidecasting below the road formation area. Topsoil will be
            stripped and stockpiled, and then respread on batters.
            Excess fill will be disposed of at low impact sites. Noise
            will be controlled by restricting work and blasting hours,
            and prohibiting the use of air horns. Finally, compensation
            will be paid for the loss of land, buildings, and crops or
            other natural resources; community assets and resources will
            be repaired or replaced; allowances will be paid and
            rehabilitation measures extended to displaced households.

Nepal - Road Maintenance and Development
